pages.text: Copper is a chemical element with the symbol Cu (from Latin: cuprum) and atomic number 29. It is a soft, malleable, and ductile metal with very high thermal and electrical conductivity. A freshly exposed surface of pure copper has a pinkish-orange color. Copper is used as a conductor of heat and electricity, as a building material, and as a constituent of various metal alloys, such as sterling $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) used in jewelry,

$(l:materials/Cupronickel)cupronickel$(/l) used to make marine hardware and coins, and $(l:materials/Constantan)constantan$(/l) used in strain gauges and thermocouples for temperature measurement.$(p)Copper is one of the few metals that can occur in nature in a directly usable metallic form (native metals). This led to very early human use in several regions, from c. 8000 BC. Thousands of years later, it was the first metal to be smelted from sulfide ores, c. 5000 BC, the

first metal to be cast into a shape in a mold, c. 4000 BC and the first metal to be purposefully alloyed with another metal, $(l:materials/Tin)tin$(/l), to create $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l), c. 3500 BC.
